Hydrodesulfurization of dibenzothiophene over NiW/(SnAlPO4-5+Al2O3) catalyst, the tuning effect of SnAlPO4-5 to the desulfurization reaction pathway Houxiang Sun Qian Wang Xinyue Zhang Qianqian Yu Lei Li Yandan Wang Baojian Shen ⁎ The Key Laboratory of Catalysis of CNPC, College of Chemical Engineering, China University of Petroleum, Beijing, 102249, China The Key Laboratory of Catalysis of CNPC College of Chemical Engineering China University of Petroleum Beijing 102249 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract SnAlPO4-5 molecular sieves were hydrothermally synthesized using SnCl2·2H2O as the tin source, and were verified that divalent tin was incorporated into the framework by isomorphous substitution of trivalent aluminum, and increasing the numbers of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites relative to those in AlPO4-5. The molecular sieves were used to fabricate hybrid supports with alumina and then were loaded with active metals to obtain NiW catalysts. The hydrodesulfurization (HDS) of dibenzothiophene (DBT) were evaluated for the catalytic activity of the catalysts. Because of the higher number of weak acid sites, much greater average number of slab layers and higher dispersion of WS2, the HDS rate of DBT at 280 °C is improved from 49.6% for the NiW/(AlPO4-5+Al2O3) catalyst to 82.2% for the NiW/(Sn0.12AlPO4-5+Al2O3) catalyst. Moreover, the highly active NiW/(Sn0.12AlPO4-5+Al2O3) catalyst obviously increases the product of the direct desulfurization route in the DBT HDS, which is beneficial for reducing hydrogen consumption in the industrial applications. Keywords AlPO4-5 Tin Isomorphous substitution Acidic sites Hydrodesulfurization Supports 1 Introduction Hydrodesulfurization (HDS) is an important process for the industrial production of clean fuels [1]. Industrial HDS catalysts are prepared from cobalt or tungsten and nickel or molybdenum in alumina. To meet the demand for clean fuel, an intense research effort is currently devoted to the design of novel HDS catalysts for both the support and active phase of the catalysts [2,3]. Regarding the supports, many zeolites have been studied as substitutes of pure alumina support in HDS catalysts [4–6]. The presence of acid sites in the support is beneficial for the catalytic activity of the HDS catalyst [7]. Mey et al. [3] reported that the catalytic performance of the HDS catalyst is related to the acidity of the support. Han et al. [8] proved that Brønsted acid sites of the support further enhanced the HDS performance and helped the catalysts to exhibit a certain isomerization activity. It is well-known that the DBT of HDS have two main pathways [9–11]: namely, the hydrogenation (HYD) route, and the direct desulfurization (DDS) route. Licea et al. [12] proved that an increasing proportion of tungsten favored the hydrogenation of DBT HDS in unsupported Ni(Co)-Mo-W sulfide catalysts. Bataille et al. [13] reviewed CoMo and Mo catalysts supported on zeolite. The activity of Mo/zeolite and production of DDS were higher than those of Mo/Al2O3. This results clearly shows that the support plays an important role in the effect of HDS pathway. As we all known, tin and silicon are both group IV A elements and have similar properties. Many articles have reported that the PtSn catalysts supported on molecular sieves exhibited high catalytic activity [14,15]. Komatsu et al. [16] reviewed that the Pt-Sn catalyst supported on H-SAPO-11 has high selectivity in the dehydroisomerization of butane. The addition of tin in Pt catalysts based on molecular sieves has a positive effect on the hydrogenation reaction. Tin also has been incorporated in different molecular sieves [17,18] and used in different catalytic reactions. Most of the reports in the literature are on the investigations of SnPt catalysts and tin-molecular sieves. However, the direct proof of the existence of tin used in the HDS reaction has not been provided in the literature. The application of molecular sieves containing tin in the HDS reaction has also been rarely reported. Zhao et al. [19] proved that the catalysts of NiW loaded AlPO4-5 and ETS-10 have a positive synergistic effect in the HDA and HDS of Daqing FCC diesel feedstock. However, the acidity and reactivity of AlPO4-5 with alternating AlO4 and PO4 tetrahedral are still restricted by the neutral framework, leading to an inadequate number of active sites [20]. In this work, to improve the catalytic activity of HDS catalysts, SnAlPO4-5 molecular sieves were prepared with a conventional hydrothermal synthesis, and used to manufacture the hybrid support of NiW catalysts with alumina. The NiW catalysts were widely characterized and evaluated in the HDS of DBT. The NiW catalysts supported on hybrid SnAlPO4-5-alumina exhibit a notable HDS activity. 2 Experiment 2.1 Synthesis of molecular sieves SnAlPO4-5 molecular sieve was hydrothermally synthesized using deionized water, pseudo–boehmite (Al2O3, 69.5%, Aluminum Corporation of China Limited), phosphoric acid (H3PO4, 85.0%, Tianjin Guangfu Fing Chemical Research Institute), two hydrated stannous chloride (SnCl2·2H2O, 99.0%, Tianjin Guangfu Fing Chemical Research Institute) and triethylamine (Et3N, 99.0%, Tianjin Guangfu Fing Chemical Research Institute) as a structure directing agent from a gel with following chemical composition: ySnO: (1-y/2)Al2O3: 1.06P2O5: 1.47Et3N: 45H2O (y = 0.06 and 0.12). The hybrid gel was typically crystallized at 180 °C for 24 h. The as-synthesized solids were filtered, washed with deionized water, and further dried at 120 °C. Then, samples were calcined at 350 °C for 2 h and 550 °C for 6 h under an air atmosphere before being characterized, and were denoted as Sn0.06AlPO4-5 and Sn0.12AlPO4-5, respectively. The SnO2/AlPO4-5 molecular sieve was prepared from SnCl2·2H2O and AlPO4-5 by the incipient-wetness impregnation. The tin content was equivalent to that of tin in the Sn0.12AlPO4-5 determined by the XRF. After the impregnation, the sample was calcined at 550 °C for 4 h. 2.2 Preparation of support and catalyst The hybrid supports (AlPO4-5+Al2O3, Sn0.06AlPO4-5+Al2O3, Sn0.12AlPO4-5+Al2O3 and SnO2/AlPO4-5+Al2O3) were prepared by mi xing AlPO4-5 or other molecular sieves (30 wt%) with Al2O3 (70 wt%), followed by extruding, drying, calcining at 550 °C for 4 h. The four catalysts with the same loading content of WO3 (27.0 wt%) and NiO (4.0 wt%) were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation with an aqueous solution of the appropriate amount of ammonium metatungstate pentahydrate ((NH4)6H2W12O40·40H2O, 85.0%, Tianjin Guangfu Fing Chemical Research Institute) and nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 98.0%, Tianjin Guangfu Fing Chemical Research Institute), dried naturally, then dried at 120 °C for 8 h and calcined 480 °C for 4 h. The catalysts were denoted as NiW/(AlPO4-5+Al2O3), NiW/(Sn0.06AlPO4-5+Al2O3), NiW/(Sn0.12AlPO4-5+Al2O3), and NiW/(SnO2/AlPO4-5+Al2O3), respectively. 2.3 Characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern was obtained using a PANalytical X’Pert Powder X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation at 40 mA and 40 kV. The samples were scanned with the step size of 0.013° and at the rate of 30 s for per step. The nitrogen physisorption measurements were determined using a Micromeritics TriStar 3020 apparatus. Prior to the measurement, the samples were degassed under vacuum (P<10−2 kPa) at 350 °C for 8 h. The t-plot methods and Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) were used to measure the pore volume and the specific surface area, respectively. The contents of bulk elements of the molecular sieves was measured by X-ray fluorescence (XRF) with an AxiosmAX spectrometer. For analysis, the sample powder (2 g) was pressed into a self-supporting disk (8.04 cm2) at 30 MPa for 30 s. The surface compositions of the molecular sieves, the oxidation state and sulfide catalysts were investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) with a Thermo Fisher K-Alpha spectrometer using Al Kα radiation (hv = 1486.6 eV). For the oxidation state and sulfide catalysts investigations, signals for the Ni2p, W4f, P2p, Al2p, S2p and Sn3d bands were recorded. The 27Al and 31P MAS NMR spectra were obtained on a Bruker-400 NMR spectrometer at 104 and 161.9 MHz, respectively. Acidity of the samples were determined by ammonia temperature desorption (NH3-TPD) using a Micromeritics Autochem 2920 instrument. For analysis, the sample (0.2000 g) was outgassed under a He flow with the heating rate (15 °C min−1) up to 600 °C and then maintained for 30 min. After cooling down to below 100 °C, an NH3 flow was passed over the sample, and then, the temperature was increased to 100 °C and maintained for 30 min to desorb the physically adsorbed NH3. The chemically adsorbed NH3 was detected by increasing the temperature from 100 °C to 600 °C at the heating rate (10 °C min−1). The NH3 desorption profile was measured using a thermal conductivity detector. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) micrographs of the sulfide phase were determined on an FEI F20 microscope at 200 kV. At least 50 micrographs of each catalyst were obtained. The stacking number and the slab length were obtained by measuring at least 300 slabs per catalyst. FT-IR spectra of pyridine were obtained using a Thermo Fisher Nicolet IS10 spectrometer with the spectral resolution of 4 cm−1. After the molecular sieve were compressed into a self-supported wafer, the wafer was set in a quartz cell. The cell was connected to a vacuum system. The wafer was heated and degassed in a pressure-tight cell at 400 °C for 2 h to remove any water in the material. Then, the wafer was cooled down to room temperature and treated with pyridine vapor for 15 min so that adsorption saturation occurred. The FT-IR spectra of the wafer were acquired at room temperature after the desorption of pyridine [21] at 150 °C for 2 h and at 300 °C for 2 h under the dynamic vacuum. The amount of Brønsted and Lewis acids were calculated according to [22]: Cpy-B  = 1.88ABR 2/m and Cpy-L  = 1.42ALR 2/m Where Cpy-B and Cpy-L are the Brønsted acid and Lewis acid amounts (mmol/g), respectively. AB and AL are the absorbance area of Brønsted and Lewis acids (cm−1), respectively. m is the amount of the wafer (mg), and R is the radius of the wafer (cm). 2.4 Catalytic activity evaluation The catalytic performance was tested in a continuous-flow fixed bed micro-reactor with the internal diameter of 10.0 mm. For the catalytic test, the oxide catalyst (1.00 g, 40–60 mesh) was placed into the constant temperature zone of the reactor and was then activated by sulfidation with a decane (98%, Tianjin Guangfu Fing Chemical Research Institute) solution containing 10 vt% CS2 (98%, Tianjin Guangfu Fing Chemical Research Institute) at 320 °C and hydrogen pressure (4.0 MPa) for 4 h. The synthetic feed was charged into the reactor containing 1000 μg/g S (DBT, 98%, Tianjin Guangfu Fing Chemical Research Institute). The catalytic reaction was controlled at 260∼320 °C, pressure 4.0 MPa, H2/oil ratio of 300 (v/v) and a feed WHSV of 8.76 h−1. During each run, the products were periodically sampled and analyzed by the ultraviolet florescence method using an RPP-2000 SN spectroscopymeter. The HDS rate was defined as follows: RDBT = (1 − CS/CS0)×100% where RDBT is the total HDS rate of DBT, respectively. CS is the total sulfur content of the corresponding product and CS0 is the total sulfur content of the corresponding feed. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of molecular sieves Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the SnAlPO4-5 molecular sieves. It can be clearly seen that all the samples have the AFI structure [23] with a high crystallinity (Table 1 ). No pattern of tin oxides phases is presented, which may be due to the low loading of tin oxide, its high distribution or the tin present in the framework. Another possibility is that the presence of amorphous (non-crystalline) phases may be responsible for the absence of the diffraction patterns of crystalline tin oxides. The surface areas of AlPO4-5, Sn0.06AlPO4-5, Sn0.12AlPO4-5 and SnO2/AlPO4-5 are 267, 251, 219 and 230 m2/g (Table 1), respectively. The AlPO4-5 exhibits the highest pore volume and surface area. Compared to that of AlPO4-5, it can be seen that the pore volume and specific surface area in the SnAlPO4-5 decrease with the increased amount of tin. For SnO2/AlPO4-5, the pore volume and specific area are slightly reduced. The molar content of Al is higher than that of P for the four samples (Table 1), which is mostly likely due to the presence of some extra framework aluminum during the molecular sieve formation. Compared with pure AlPO4-5, SnAlPO4-5 has a lower Al molar content because tin replaces Al in the framework. The tin content of SnAlPO4-5 increases with the increase of tin content in the gel. The surfaces of Sn/Al atomic ratios in the SnAlPO4-5 and SnO2/AlPO4-5 are greater than that of the bulk, suggesting Sn surface enrichment. The 27Al MAS NMR spectra of four molecular sieves (Fig. 2 ) are dominated by the peak 35.2 ppm, which is attributed to Al(4 P) [24]. The 31P spectra of AlPO4-5, SnAlPO4-5 and SnO2/AlPO4-5 show a sharp peak at approximately -32 ppm, which is denoted as P(4Al) and is associated with the tetrahedral phosphorous linked to four –OAl groups [25]. Moreover, a low intense wide band (approximately -17.1 ppm) with low intensity appeared near the P (4Al) signal in SnAlPO4-5. The intensity of this signal slightly increases with the tin content increase in SnAlPO4-5, which is likely due to the existence of P(4-nAl, nSn) (n = 1–4) [26]. A similar type of observation is also made for the incorporation of other divalent metal ions incorporation into the AFI framework [27,28]. This result implies that the synthesis of SnAlPO4-5 likely proceeded via the isomorphous substitution of Sn2+ for Al3+. The NH3-TPD profiles of four samples are presented in Fig. 3 . The NH3-TPD patterns of AlPO4-5 and SnO2/AlPO4-5 only show a desorption peak at approximately 159 °C. SnAlPO4-5 molecular sieves show two desorption peaks at approximately 161 and 271 °C. The peak at approximately 271 °C may be related to the divalent tin incorporated into the framework. Similar type of observations were also reported for CoAlPO4-5 [28], ZnAlPO4-5 and MgAlPO4-5 [29]. Additionally, the acidity of SnAlPO4-5 increases obviously with the increase in tin content. The acidity of SnAlPO4-5 was higher than those of SnO2/AlPO4-5 and AlPO4-5. The FT-IR spectra of the pyridine adsorption region of four samples are displayed in Fig. 4 and Table 2 . Here, the peak at 1544 cm−1 is assigned to the pyridine adsorbed on the Brønsted acid sites [30], the absorption peaks at approximately 1448 and 1456 cm−1 are assigned to the Lewis acid sites [31] and the peak appearing at approximately 1491 cm−1 is attributed to pyridine chemisorption on both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites [32]. The pure AlPO4-5 has absent the Brønsted acid sites and only has a few Lewis acid sites (Table 2). With the increase tin in the tin content in SnAlPO4-5, the number of weak Lewis acid sites increased obviously, and the number of weak Brønsted acid sites increased slightly, similar to the effect of the isomorphous substitution of trivalent aluminum by a divalent metal in the framework of AlPO4-5 [33,34]. 3.2 Characterization of catalysts Fig. 5 shows the XRD profiles of the four oxide catalysts. The peaks with the γ-Al2O3 and AFI structures appear in all catalysts, and their intensities are virtually identical. The absence of additional peaks of any NiO and WO3 species suggests that nickel and tungsten species are evenly distributed [35]. This suggests that W and Ni oxide species are either completely amorphous or that their crystallites are too small to yield XRD signals. The four catalysts have the same content of active metal oxides (27 wt% WO3 and 4.0 wt% NiO). The hybrid supports contain the same amounts of Al2O3 (70 wt%) and of molecular sieve (30 wt%). Textural data of four NiW catalysts (Table 3 ) show that the pore volume and specific surface area are similar as well. This result indicates that the difference of the pore volume and specific surface area in the catalysts can be neglected for the catalytic activity in the HDS reaction. For the four catalysts, the acidity mainly arises from the hybrid support (alumina and molecular sieves). The four catalysts contain the same active metals and alumina, and only the molecular sieves with the content of 30 wt% are different in four hybrid supports, so that the difference in the acidities of the catalysts are mainly due to the corresponding molecular sieves. During the presulfuration process, the active metals (Ni and W) change from the oxide state into the sulfide state. The Py-IR results for the acid-type distribution of the four catalysts are presented in Table 4 . The amount of acid increases in the following order: NiW/(AlPO4-5+Al2O3) <NiW/(SnO2/AlPO4-5+Al2O3) <NiW/(Sn0.06AlPO4-5+Al2O3) <NiW/ (Sn0.12AlPO4-5+Al2O3), which is consistent with the order of the total acidity of the corresponding molecular sieves in hybrid supports. The total acidity of the catalyst NiW/(AlPO4-5+Al2O3) is greater than that of AlPO4-5 because of the greater number of acid sites in Al2O3 than that in AlPO4-5 [36]. Although the total acidities of catalyst NiW/(Sn0.06AlPO4-5+Al2O3) and NiW/(SnO2/AlPO4-5+Al2O3) (Table 2) are greater than that of AlPO4-5, they are still lower than that of alumina. The total acidity of Sn0.12AlPO4-5 is much greater than that of alumina. Therefore, with the exception of the catalyst NiW/(SnAlPO4-5+Al2O3), the total acidity of the catalyst was increased compared to those corresponding molecular sieves. Compared to the catalyst NiW/(AlPO4-5+Al2O3), the total acidity of catalyst NiW/(SnO2/AlPO4-5+Al2O3) is increased slightly. The total acidity, and the amounts of weak Brønsted and Lewis acid sites are increased obviously by the introduction of SnAlPO4-5 in the catalysts, especially for the catalyst NiW/(Sn0.12AlPO4-5+Al2O3), which is beneficial for the HDS reaction. To further investigate the distribution of active metals on the surface of the catalysts and the extent of sulfidation extent, the freshly obtained sulfide catalysts and oxide catalysts were analyzed by XPS. In the Ni2p XPS of the oxide catalysts, the two main peaks (Table 5 ) are attributed to the spin-splitting Ni 2p3/2 (approximately 856.2 eV) and 2p1/2 (approximately 873.8 eV). Fig. 6 shows the Ni2p XPS spectra of the sulfide catalysts. The peaks are associated with Ni-S (approximately 852.4 eV), Ni-W-S (approximately 854.0 eV), Ni2+ (approximately 856.5 eV) and the shakeup of Ni2+ (approximately 862.5 eV) [37]. The Ni2p peak at 852.4∼854.0 eV, together with the presence of the S2p peaks at 161.9 and 163.0 eV, are attributed to nickel sulfides. The Ni2p signal clearly shows that the existence of oxidation state Ni2+ species in the four catalysts after sulfidation [38]. Moreover, there are some electronic of Ni atoms transfer to adjacent WS2 (Ni-W-S phase). In the NiW catalysts, the existence of Ni sulfides with the Ni-W-S phases is the most active phase compared to WS2 and NiS, which has been proved in the literature [39]. The Ni species can improve the formation of tungsten sulfide in the NiW catalysts. The catalysts NiW/(SnAlPO4-5+Al2O3), especially NiW/(Sn0.12AlPO4-5+Al2O3), have more Ni-W-S species than other catalysts, indicating a higher catalytic activity. The S2p spectra (Fig. 7 ) of sulfide catalysts exhibited only one doublet peaks at approximately 161.9 and 163.0 eV, which can be attributed to S2+ 2p3/2 and 2p1/2, respectively [35,40]. No other signal around the binding energy of 169.0 eV is identified, suggesting that no oxidation of the catalysts occurred, and no sulfate species are presented during the transfer of the sulfide catalysts and the XPS measurement process. The binding energies of the W4f spectra in oxidized catalysts (Fig. 8 a) are found at approximately 37.9 and 35.7 eV, and are assigned to the signals of W4f5/2 and W4f7/2, respectively [35]. After sulfidation of catalysts (Fig. 8b), the binding energies of W4f7/2 and W4f5/2 for W6+ (WO3) are approximately 35.7 and 37.9 eV, respectively, those for W5+ (WOS) are approximately 32.8 and 34.8 eV, and those for W4+ (WS2) are approximately 32.4 and 34.4 eV [39,41]. The W4+ species is the main catalytically active sites in the NiW catalysts. The sulfidation degree (Wsulfidation) of the W species is defined as the ratio of WS2 (W4+) to the sum of WS2 (W4+), WOS (W5+), and WO3 (W6+) [42], and it can be approximately predicted by the atomic ratio of W4+/(W4++W5++W6+). The Wsulfidation (Table 5) decreases in the following order: NiW/(Sn0.12AlPO4-5+Al2O3) (38.5%)> NiW/(Sn0.06AlPO4-5+Al2O3) (37.2%)> NiW/(AlPO4-5+Al2O3) (36.5%)> NiW/(SnO2/AlPO4-5+Al2O3) (25.4%). It can be seen that the catalysts NiW/(SnAlPO4-5+Al2O3) and especially the NiW/(Sn0.12AlPO4-5+Al2O3) appear to be sulfide more easily because of the addition of SnAlPO4-5, indicating a greater content of the sulfide active phase and higher catalytic activity. Table 5 shows the surface species distributions. It can be clearly seen from the data that the surface concentrations of Ni and W relative to P + Al in the catalysts are all lower than the theoretical ratios of Ni/P + Al and W/P + Al (these theoretical ratios are equivalent to 0.048 and 0.104, respectively), suggesting that the Ni and W species are non-uniformly dispersed on the surface of support. For the oxide catalysts, the catalysts NiW/(Sn0.12AlPO4-5+Al2O3) and NiW/(SnO2/AlPO4-5+Al2O3) have higher Ni/P + Al and W/P + Al than do the other catalysts, indicating that a greater content of Ni and W is present on the surface of the Sn0.12AlPO4-5+Al2O3 and SnO2/AlPO4-5+Al2O3 supports. The use of the support Sn0.12AlPO4-5+Al2O3 leads to a higher W/Ni ratio. The surface ratios of W/Ni in the sulfurized catalysts are lower than that of the corresponding oxide catalyst. It has been proved that the W species are mainly distributed in the vacancies on the surface of the alumina and molecular sieve, while the Ni species are evenly distributed throughout the entire support [35]. During sulfidation, the surface W/Ni and W/P + Al molar ratios decreased on the catalysts with the exception of NiW/(AlPO4-5+Al2O3), and W/Ni and W/P + Al molar ratios show that the decrease in the W species amount is greater than that for the Ni species amount. During sulfidation, Ni and W species gradually changed from oxide state to sulfide state, and were rearranged [35], which caused a decrease in the apparent coverage of the supports by W because the formation of WS2 slabs by a significant lateral agglomeration of the W phase. Compared to the NiW/(AlPO4-5+Al2O3) and NiW/(SnO2/AlPO4-5+Al2O3) catalysts, the NiW/(SnAlPO4-5+Al2O3) catalysts have lower atomic ratios of W/P + Al, and Ni/P + Al despite the same metal content, suggesting that the higher dispersion of W and Ni provide more Ni–W–S active sites. Furthermore, the dispersion of Ni is restricted by that of W at a certain extent beyond which the NiSx phases would occur and be segregation [43]. Significantly, the W species are considered as the secondary support of Ni species in the NiW catalysts, so that the dispersion of Ni can be improved by the higher dispersion of W species. The sulfide active phase of the catalysts can be estimated by the ratio of S/Ni + W. The S/Ni + W (Table 5) increases in the following order: NiW/(AlPO4-5+Al2O3) (1.34)< NiW/(SnO2/AlPO4-5+Al2O3) (1.44)< NiW/(Sn0.06AlPO4-5+Al2O3) (1.45)< NiW/(Sn0.12AlPO4-5+Al2O3) (1.49), corresponding to WS2 phase formation. The results demonstrate that the NiW catalysts supported on the hybrid SnAlPO4-5-alumina contribute to the weakest tungstate-support interaction and are vulcanized more easily, indicating the easier formation of the active Ni–W–S phases. Therefore, it can be presumed that the catalysts containing SnAlPO4-5 show a higher activity in the HDS reaction. Fig. 9 shows representative TEM micrographs of the four sulfide catalysts. The TEM micrographs reveal the existence of typical WS2 slab-like structure. In the model of Ni-W-S phase, NiS is present in the alumina lattice or is located at the edges in five-fold coordinated sites at the edge planes of WS2 and is considered to be a source of promoter atoms [35]. Because of their limited presence and the good dispersion, NiS crystals are too small or less than 4 nm to be directly detected in the sulfide catalysts by TEM. According to the reports in the literature [44,45], the average slab length ( L ¯ ), number of layers ( N ¯ ) and WS2 dispersion (fw ) are calculated as follows: (1) L ¯ = ∑ i = 1 n x i L i ∑ i = 1 n x i (2) N ¯ = ∑ i = 1 n x i N i ∑ i = 1 n x i (3) f W = ∑ i = 1 t 6 n i - 6 ∑ i = 1 t 3 n i 2 - 3 n i + 1 where Ni and Li are layer number and the length of WS2 slabs in each stack, respectively, xi is the number of WS2 slabs possessing with number of layers Ni or length Li , t is the number of slabs and ni is the number of W atoms along one edge of a WS2 slab calculated using its length (L = 3.2(2ni -1)Å). The results of calculation (Table 5) show that the WS2 dispersion (f W) over the four catalysts is as follows: NiW/(Sn0.12AlPO4-5+Al2O3)> NiW/(Sn0.06AlPO4-5+Al2O3)> NiW/(SnO2/AlPO4-5+Al2O3)> NiW/(Sn0.12AlPO4-5+Al2O3). Among the four catalyst, the highest WS2 dispersion over the NiW/(Sn0.12AlPO4-5+Al2O3) catalyst can efficiently improve the Ni atom occupation on the edge sites of WS2 slabs and is beneficial for the formation of the Ni-W-S phase [46]. The distribution of the stacking number and the slab lengths of WS2 particles are shown in Fig. 10 . Compared to the NiW/(AlPO4-5+Al2O3) catalyst, both the NiW/(Sn0.06AlPO4-5+Al2O3) and NiW/(Sn0.12AlPO4-5+Al2O3) catalysts display wider distributions of the numbers of layers and the slab length. The average stacking number and the average length of the NiW catalysts supported on hybrid AlPO4-5-alumina are 1.80 and 2.93 nm, respectively. The average stacking number and the average length of the NiW catalysts supported on hybrid Sn0.12AlPO4-5-alumina are 2.48 and 3.28 nm, respectively. The average stacking numbers and the average length of NiW/(SnO2/AlPO4-5+Al2O3) are 1.71 and 3.00 nm, respectively. For the NiW/(Sn0.12AlPO4-5+Al2O3) catalyst, the distributions of stacking number and slab lengths of WS2 broaden (Fig.10). The Sn of the catalysts is contributed by the SnAlPO4-5, and the P/Al ratios of molecular sieves are almost constant. Therefore, the use of different support components (the presence and content of tin in molecular sieves) does not only lead to a difference in the crystalline phases of WS2, but also influences the degree of sulfidation. Therefore, the physicochemical properties and catalytic activity of the catalysts supported on hybrid SnAlPO4-5-alumina are likely different from that of the catalyst containing AlPO4-5 or SnO2/AlPO4-5. The average stacking number of the WS2 phase (Table 5) can be measured by the TEM, which were found to vary from 1.71 to 2.48, and the average dimensions of the WS2 crystallites varied from 2.93 to 3.28 nm. The statistical results for the NiW/(Sn0.12AlPO4-5+Al2O3) catalysts show that the WS2 slabs have an average stacking layer number of 2.48, an average length of 3.28 nm, and a dispersion of 0.47, indicating that the dispersion of the W species can be obviously improved by addition of Sn0.12AlPO4-5 in the catalyst. 3.3 Catalytic activity evaluation The results of DBT HDS over four NiW catalysts at 260 °C, 280 °C and 300 °C are presented in Table 6 . It is found that all NiW catalysts show higher HDS rate of DBT than that of the NiW/Al2O3 catalyst (the HDS rate of DBT is 21.6%, 45.7% and 71.9% at 260 °C, 280 °C and 300 °C, respectively, under the same reaction conditions), which is consistent with the results of our previous research [19]. The DBT HDS rate over five catalysts is as follows: NiW/(Sn0.12AlPO4-5+Al2O3)> NiW/(Sn0.06AlPO4-5+Al2O3) > NiW/(SnO2/AlPO4-5+Al2O3)> NiW/(AlPO4-5+ Al2O3)> NiW/Al2O3. The NiW catalyst supported on hybrid AlPO4-5-alumina shows the lowest activity, with a DBT HDS rate of only 22.4% at 260 °C, 49.6% at 280 °C and 83.8% at 300 °C. The NiW catalyst supported on hybrid Sn0.12AlPO4-5-alumina shows the highest activity, giving DBT HDS rate 44.1% at 260 °C, 82.2% at 280 °C and 98.2% at 300 °C. The NiW/(SnO2/AlPO4-5+Al2O3) catalyst shows a slightly increase. Generally, the catalysts supported on hybrid SnAlPO4-5-alumina have higher catalytic activity than those of other catalysts supported on hybrid AlPO4-5-alumina or SnO2/AlPO4-5-alumina. The products of DBT HDS were detected by GC–MS in order to analyze the abilities of hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis over the NiW catalysts with different hybrid molecular sieve-alumina. The mechanism of DBT in the HDS reaction can go through two parallel pathways [47] as shown in Fig. 11 . The product of DDS is biphenyl (BP), and the products of HDY are tetrahydrodibenzothiophene (THDBT), hexahydro-dibenzothiophene (HHDBT), cyclohexylbenzene (CHB) and bicyclohexyl (BCH). The selectivity of the pathway (HYD/DDS ratio) could be calculated by the yields ratio (1-BP)/BP. The results for the path selectivity of HYD and DDS at 280 °C are shown in Table 6. The HYD/DDS ratios of DBT in four catalysts are as follows: NiW/(AlPO4-5+Al2O3)> NiW/(SnO2/AlPO4-5+Al2O3)> NiW/(Sn0.06AlPO4-5+Al2O3) > NiW/(Sn0.12AlPO4-5+Al2O3), indicating that the DDS pathway increased more in the DBT HDS with the addition of SnAlPO4-5. For the NiW/(SnAlPO4-5+Al2O3) catalyst, the relative amount of BP is larger than that of CHB because BP increases to a greater extents than CHB with SnAlPO4-5 does. Finally, the comparison of the calculated HYD/DDS ratio calculated indicates that the presence of SnAlPO4-5 slightly improves the DDS route of the HDS reaction compared to that of the catalyst supported on hybrid AlPO4-5-alumina. The above assessment results of DBT have certified that the NiW/(SnAlPO4-5+Al2O3) catalyst has a higher performance than the other catalysts do. The differences between the four catalysts are mainly due to the differences between the molecular sieves in the hybrid support. The addition of SnAlPO4-5 in the NiW catalyst improves the acidity (Table 4) and the tunes size and structure of WS2 (Fig. 10 and Table 5) are important factors to determine the catalytic activity of HDS catalysts because the edge of the WS2 slabs is considered to contain the active sites for hydrogenation [35]. The greater number of edge sites of WS2 slabs can provide greater HDS activity. According to the literature results [48,49], it is proposed that the edge sites are DDS-oriented, and the brim sites (the top and bottom layers of the multilayers) in the Ni-W-S and W-S phases are both HYD-oriented and DDS-oriented. Compared to NiW/(AlPO4-5+Al2O3) catalyst, NiW/(SnAlPO4-5+Al2O3) catalysts, especially NiW/(Sn0.12AlPO4-5+Al2O3), have more multi-layers and edge sites of WS2 (Table 5 and Fig. 10b), which caused that the product of DDS increased more than the products of HYD in the HDS of DBT. For the same metal content, the NiW/(SnAlPO4-5+Al2O3) catalyst provides more active metal sulfide sites. Apparently, Sn0.12AlPO4-5 is more favorable for HDS than others molecular sieves in the NiW catalysts. The presence of SnAlPO4-5 in the hybrid support tunes the WS2 structures and sizes and the catalytic activity of the NiW catalysts. It has been recognized that the presence of acid sites enhances the activity of the sulfide phase and that Brønsted acids are beneficial for the HDS reaction or act as structural promoters by increasing the electronic deficiency of the metal active phase [6,50], and the improved electronic deficiency can increase the HDS ability of the catalysts containing zeolite-alumina [51]. Furthermore, the Brønsted acidity of NiW catalysts has a marked influence the dispersion of tungsten sulfide and the adsorption of the aromatic molecules. Therefore, the NiW/(Sn0.12AlPO4-5+Al2O3) catalyst with more acid sites, especially weak Brønsted acid sites, has higher activity for the DBT HDS than that of other catalysts. This new finding has an important practical implications for the development of HDS catalysts. 4 Conclusions Highly crystallized SnAlPO4-5 molecular sieves with SnCl2·2H2O as the tin source are successfully synthesized via the hydrothermal synthesis method. Tin is enriched on the crystal surface of SnAlPO4-5. Most importantly, divalent tin is incorporated by isomorphous substitution for Al3+ in the framework of SnAlPO4-5, which caused more Brønsted and Lewis acid sites than those of pure AlPO4-5. The application of SnAlPO4-5 molecular sieves as components of supports in NiW catalysts improves the sulfidation of the catalysts. The stacking number distribution and the slab length of WS2 in the catalyst of NiW/(SnAlPO4-5+Al2O3) become wider than that of AlPO4-5. The average numbers of the slab layers and average slabs length of the NiW catalysts supported on hybrid Sn0.12AlPO4-5-alumina increase from 1.80 to 2.48 and from 2.93 nm to 3.28 nm, respectively. Compared to NiW/(AlPO4-5+Al2O3), the NiW/(Sn0.12AlPO4-5+Al2O3) catalyst exhibits a higher DBT HDS rate, which is increased from 49.6% to 82.2% at 280 °C. The addition of SnAlPO4-5 in the support of NiW catalysts improved the acidity, WS2 dispersion and structure of the active metal phase. The considerably enhanced catalytic performance is mainly due to the increased amount of the acid and the tuning of WS2 structures and distribution. Furthermore, the DBT reacts preferentially through the HYD route on the NiW/(AlPO4-5+Al2O3) catalyst. However, the product of DDS route increase on the NiW/(SnAlPO4-5+Al2O3) catalyst, which could reduce the hydrogen consumption in the potential industrial application. coredata.dc:description: SnAlPO4-5 molecular sieves were hydrothermally synthesized using SnCl2·2H2O as the tin source, and were verified that divalent tin was incorporated into the framework by isomorphous substitution of trivalent aluminum, and increasing the numbers of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites relative to those in AlPO4-5. The molecular sieves were used to fabricate hybrid supports with alumina and then were loaded with active metals to obtain NiW catalysts. The hydrodesulfurization (HDS) of dibenzothiophene (DBT) were evaluated for the catalytic activity of the catalysts. Because of the higher number of weak acid sites, much greater average number of slab layers and higher dispersion of WS2, the HDS rate of DBT at 280 °C is improved from 49.6% for the NiW/(AlPO4-5+Al2O3) catalyst to 82.2% for the NiW/(Sn0.12AlPO4-5+Al2O3) catalyst. Moreover, the highly active NiW/(Sn0.12AlPO4-5+Al2O3) catalyst obviously increases the product of the direct desulfurization route in the DBT HDS, which is beneficial for reducing hydrogen consumption in the industrial applications.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrodesulfurization of dibenzothiophene over NiW/(SnAlPO4-5+Al2O3) catalyst, the tuning effect of SnAlPO4-5 to the desulfurization reaction pathway
